Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is motivated by several classical areas of mathematics. The main tools come from combinatorics, including combinatorial topology, algebraic combinatorics, and the machinery of quiver mutations. Combinatorics deals with discrete objects such as finite sets, graphs, permutations, partial orders, etc. Many continuous phenomena allow for a discrete representation, lending themselves amenable to combinatorial methods of study. It is often the case that identical or similar combinatorial structures underlie seemingly unrelated mathematical entities, revealing hidden connections between these and allowing the transfer of insights and techniques from one discipline to another. A case in point is the theory of cluster algebras, which are the main focus of this project.

This award supports the PI's research on combinatorial structures arising in algebra and geometry, with an emphasis on the theory and applications of cluster algebras. Cluster algebras, discovered by the PI in collaboration with A. Zelevinsky, have found applications in several mathematical disciplines including representation theory, Teichmueller theory, mathematical physics, and enumerative and geometric combinatorics. The investigator intends to further explore the connections between cluster algebras, on one hand, and classical invariant theory and projective geometry, on the other. Another research direction concerns algebraic complexity for computational models employing a restricted set of arithmetic operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of this project was on the theory and applications of cluster algebras and related combinatorics, and on their connections with classical invariant theory, projective geometry, and other fields of mathematics. Other research directions pursued within the framework of this grant concerned algebraic complexity for computational models employing a restricted set of arithmetic operations, and the study of noncommutative Schur functions.

The PI Sergey Fomin continued his work on the monograph on cluster algebras, joint with Lauren Williams and the late Andrei Zelevinsky. This book, whose first several chapters have been posted online, aims to lay out the foundations of the basic theory of cluster algebras.

Over the course of this grant, the PI established new criteria for commutation relations among noncommutative elementary polynomials and their generalizations; further developed tensor-diagrammatic machinery for planar projective geometry; obtained new bounds on semiring complexity of Schur polynomials; and developed new extensions and applications of the theory of noncommutative Schur functions. Five publications co-authored by the PI acknowledge the support from this grant.

The PI supervised several graduate students and postdocs, and continued to maintain the online Cluster Algebras Portal.

Broader impacts of the PI's activities include his work as the Managing Editor of the Journal of the American Mathematical Society, and as the member of the Council of the AMS.
